head.title: General Efficacy of Atomically Dispersed Pt Catalysts for the Chlorine Evolution Reaction: Potential-Dependent Switching of the Kinetics and Mechanism | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: General Efficacy of Atomically Dispersed Pt Catalysts for the Chlorine Evolution Reaction: Potential-Dependent Switching of the Kinetics and Mechanism

The electrochemical chlorine evolution reaction (CER) is a key anodic reaction in the chlor-alkali process for Cl2 production, on-site generation of ClO–, and Cl2-mediated electrosynthesis. Although Ru-based mixed metal oxides have long been used as CER catalysts, they suffer from a selectivity problem due to the competing oxygen evolution reaction. To overcome this shortcoming, we have developed a new CER catalyst composed of atomically dispersed Pt–N4 sites on carbon nanotubes (Pt1/CNT). In this study, we demonstrate that the catalytically active Pt–N4 sites can be constructed from H2PtCl6·6H2O and an ionic liquid via a bottom-up approach and a Pt-porphyrin-driven top-down method. Both catalysts exhibit excellent CER activity and remarkable selectivity, demonstrating the general efficacy of Pt1/CNT for the CER. The electrochemical and in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses reveal that Pt1/CNT catalysts show a reaction order of ∼1.8 in the low overpotential regime, where the Volmer step is reconciled with the rate-determining step (RDS). Interestingly, in the high overpotential region, the CER over Pt1/CNT proceeds with a lower reaction order and the RDS switches to the Heyrovský step. These unprecedented kinetic insights are clearly distinguished from the oxide-based CER catalysts with the opposite sequence of the RDS.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
The electrochemical chlorine evolution reaction (CER) is a key anodic reaction in the chlor-alkali process for Cl
2
production, on-site generation of ClO
–
, and Cl
2
-mediated electrosynthesis. Although Ru-based mixed metal oxides have long been used as CER catalysts, they suffer from a selectivity problem due to the competing oxygen evolution reaction. To overcome this shortcoming, we have developed a new CER catalyst composed of atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
sites on carbon nanotubes (Pt
1
/CNT). In this study, we demonstrate that the catalytically active Pt–N
4
sites can be constructed from H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O and an ionic liquid via a bottom-up approach and a Pt-porphyrin-driven top-down method. Both catalysts exhibit excellent CER activity and remarkable selectivity, demonstrating the general efficacy of Pt
1
/CNT for the CER. The electrochemical and in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses reveal that Pt
1
/CNT catalysts show a reaction order of ∼1.8 in the low overpotential regime, where the Volmer step is reconciled with the rate-determining step (RDS). Interestingly, in the high overpotential region, the CER over Pt
1
/CNT proceeds with a lower reaction order and the RDS switches to the Heyrovský step. These unprecedented kinetic insights are clearly distinguished from the oxide-based CER catalysts with the opposite sequence of the RDS.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Chlorine (Cl
2
) is one of the most important chemicals for the chemical industry, with an annual global production reaching 75 million tons.
(1)
Chlorine is utilized extensively in a wide range of industrial sectors, including the production of polymers and pharmaceuticals, bleaching wood, and the treatment of waste water and ballast water.
(2,3)
Moreover, Cl
2
-mediated electrosynthesis has recently received increasing attention as an environmentally benign route to the production of industrially important chemicals such as ethylene oxide and propylene oxide.
(4,5)
The direct production or on-site generation of Cl
2
relies predominantly on the membrane-based chlor-alkali electrolyzer, in which Cl
2
gas is generated via the chlorine evolution reaction (CER) at the anode in an aqueous environment. Over the last half-century, the mainstay of CER catalysts has been mixed metal oxides, with a notable example of the dimensionally stable anode (DSA), which typically consists of RuO
2
, IrO
2
, and TiO
2
.
(6−8)
The DSAs exhibit high catalytic activity toward the CER with remarkable decade-long stability.
(7−11)
However, DSAs require at least 30 atom % of expensive precious metals to preserve electrical conductivity, which is critical to afford high catalytic activity.
(9−11)
Moreover, the surface of a DSA undergoes compositional and structural changes during the CER invoking surface inhomogeneity, which renders the identification of the active site difficult.
(12)

One of the critical challenges in the chlor-alkali electrolyzer is the catalytic selectivity at the anode. As the CER and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) share a similar potential window, given that the standard electrode potentials (
U
0
) amount to 1.36 [vs standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)] and 1.23 V [vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)], respectively, the OER competes with CER as a parasitic side reaction. While the CER involving two-electron (2e
–
) transfer exhibits much faster kinetics than the 4e
–
transfer OER,
(13)
the relatively lower
U
0
of the OER leads the anode to concurrently generate O
2
.
(8−12)
To steer the catalytic selectivity toward the CER, the chlor-alkali electrolyzer system is operated using a high chloride concentration and low pH to lower the equilibrium potential of the CER. Nonetheless, the pH of the anode in the chlor-alkali electrolyzer cannot be lowered below pH 2 because of the chemical and mechanical degradation of the perfluorinated ion-exchange membranes (e.g., Nafion).
(14)
In the case of mixed metal oxide catalysts, this pH limit inevitably leads to the formation of gaseous oxygen as a byproduct. The selectivity issue becomes more critical for the water chlorination and Cl
2
-mediated electrosynthesis, as these processes are usually operated in low chloride concentration or complicated electrolyte composition.
(2−5)
Recent computational and experimental studies have suggested the origin of the intrinsic selectivity problem of the CER in that the key reaction intermediates in the CER and OER over mixed metal oxide catalysts (e.g., DSAs), OCl and OOH, respectively, are connected by a scaling relationship, which implies that electrocatalysts with high CER activity are also reasonably active in the OER.
(10,15−22)

To promote the selectivity of a catalyst toward the CER rather than the OER, various strategies have been pursued, including the optimization of the electrolysis conditions,
(23)
control over the metal composition,
(17,21,24−29)
and the introduction of new catalysts.
(22,30−32)
Recently, we have uncovered a new CER catalyst comprising atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
active sites on carbon nanotubes (Pt
1
/CNT) from a Pt-porphyrin precursor possessing a Pt–N
4
moiety.
(31)
Pt
1
/CNT exhibited high CER activity and selectivity while efficiently inhibiting the competing OER. Notably, Pt
1
/CNT maintained its excellent CER selectivity even under low chloride concentrations and at neutral pH, whereas the CER selectivity of mixed metal oxides significantly decreased because of the scaling relationship. We theoretically identified Pt–N
4
-containing species as the active sites responsible for the highly selective CER and showed that the CER over Pt
1
/CNT proceeds with preadsorbed Cl instead of OCl, suggesting the possibility of breaking the scaling relationship that has plagued mixed metal oxide catalysts. However, detailed kinetics or a plausible mechanism for the CER over Pt
1
/CNT catalysts has not yet been verified experimentally.

In this work, we demonstrate the general efficacy of Pt–N
4
sites generated from different synthetic routes toward the CER and illustrate that the CER over the Pt–N
4
sites proceeds with an unusual potential-dependent switching of the kinetics and mechanism. The Pt–N
4
sites could be generated from the two different synthetic pathways, either using a widely available Pt precursor (H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O) and an ionic liquid (IL) in a bottom-up manner [Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)] or using Pt-porphyrin in a top-down manner [Pt
1
/CNT(P)]. Both the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl) and Pt
1
/CNT(P) catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity and selectivity toward the CER in acidic media. Kinetic analyses using Cl
–
concentration- and pH-dependent CER activity measurements reveal that the CER on Pt
1
/CNT(Cl) and Pt
1
/CNT(P) proceeds with a reaction order of ∼1.8 in the low overpotential region (1.41 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE), which can be explained by the Heyrovský–Volmer mechanism with the Volmer step as a rate-determining step (RDS). Interestingly, by combining in situ electrochemical XAS with kinetic analyses, we demonstrate that, in the high overpotential region, the reaction order decreases and the RDS switches to the Heyrovský step, thus giving rise to an unusual Volmer–Heyrovský sequence as the RDS, which is in contrast to the CER over mixed metal oxides.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, two series of Pt
1
/CNT catalysts were prepared via bottom-up and top-down approaches, as illustrated in
Figure
1
. The bottom-up approach uses the widely available H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O precursor. This method relies on the strong coordination ability of heteroatoms (e.g., nitrogen) toward the H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O precursor, which can mitigate the agglomeration of the adsorbed H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O during the impregnation or thermal activation step.
(34)
The bottom-up synthesis starts by coating CNT with 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][TFSI]) IL by physical mixing at room temperature (RT). The adsorbed IL molecules were pyrolyzed upon annealing at 450 °C to afford a nitrogen-rich carbonaceous layer on the CNT surface. The H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O precursor was impregnated onto the carbonaceous layer-coated CNT, which was then subjected to a high-temperature annealing to endow structural integrity with the support. A set of Pt
1
/CNT catalysts was also prepared via the top-down approach using Pt-porphyrin [Pt(II) tetraphenylporphine (PtTPP)] as a precursor.
(31)
The Pt–N
4
structure contained in PtTPP was consolidated on the CNT support upon a simple annealing step of the CNT adsorbed with the PtTPP precursor molecules. The thermal annealing temperatures used for both the bottom-up and top-down syntheses were varied between 500 and 800 °C, and the resulting catalysts were denoted as Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
(
X
= annealing temperature), respectively. The Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 catalysts exhibited the highest CER activity within each set of catalysts (
vide infra
). The inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and combustion elemental analysis (EA) results revealed that Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 consisted of 3.3 wt % Pt and 8.7 wt % N, while Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 consisted of 2.8 wt % Pt and 0.8 wt % N (
Table S1
). The high N content in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 originates from the IL-driven, N-rich carbonaceous layer. We note that the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts were free of sulfur and fluorine, indicating that the [TFSI] anion in the IL was removed during the thermal annealing step (
Table S1
). For benchmark purposes, we also prepared Pt nanoparticles (NPs) supported on CNTs (PtNP/CNT).

div.p:
Figure 1. Synthetic schemes of two synthetic approaches with different precursors for the preparation of the atomically dispersed Pt
1
/CNT catalysts.

div.div:
The atomically dispersed Pt sites on the catalysts were visualized using high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM). The images of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 (
Figures
2
a and
S1a,c
) show uniformly distributed ultrasmall white dots corresponding to the atomically dispersed Pt sites without the presence of large Pt NPs. The HAADF-STEM images of Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 (
Figures
2
b and
S1b,d
) also indicate the formation of uniformly generated single Pt sites. The X-ray diffraction patterns of all Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts (
Figure S2
) showed diffraction peaks corresponding to graphitic carbon structure only suggesting the absence of crystalline Pt.

div.p:
Figure 2. HAADF-STEM images of (a) Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and (b) Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700. (c) Pt 4f and (d) N 1s XPS spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800, Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp, CNT_IL-800, Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, and PtTPP precursor.

div.div:
The electronic structure of the atomically dispersed Pt sites in Pt
1
/CNT catalysts was assessed using Pt 4f X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS,
Figures
2
c and
S3a
). The deconvoluted Pt 4f XPS spectrum of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 (
Figure
2
c) exhibited only one doublet at 73.0 eV (Pt 4f
7/2
) and 76.3 eV (Pt 4f
5/2
) corresponding to the Pt
2+
state. The other Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts also showed only a single doublet for Pt
2+
in their Pt 4f XPS spectra (
Figure S3a
). All Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts showed no XPS peaks corresponding to fully reduced Pt, which were observed for PtNP/CNT (
Figure S3a and Table S2
). The deconvoluted XPS spectrum of H
2
PtCl
6
-impregnated Pt
1
/CNT(Cl) [Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp] presented a doublet for Pt
2+
at 72.5 and 75.8 eV, along with a very low-intensity doublet for Pt
4+
. Comparing the XPS spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp and Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800, the peak position for the Pt
2+
state shifted positively in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 upon annealing 800 °C, indicating the slight oxidation of Pt. XPS spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 and the other Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts were very similar to that of the PtTPP precursor, suggesting that the Pt–N coordination structure of PtTPP was mostly preserved even after the high-temperature annealing step (
Figures
2
c and
S3b
). Notably, the highly active Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 catalysts exhibited similar Pt 4f XPS spectra to each other.

The N 1s XPS spectra of the atomically dispersed metallic sites can provide information on the states of the metal-coordinated nitrogen species.
(35,36)
The N 1s binding energy of the Pt–N
4
species in the PtTPP precursor was measured to be 399.4 eV, which is identical to the previously reported value (
Figure
2
d).
(37)
The deconvoluted N 1s spectra of both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 exhibited a peak at 399.4 eV, suggesting that the atomically dispersed Pt
2+
species in the two catalysts were bound to similar N species. Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 showed additional peaks corresponding to pyridinic, pyrrolic, graphitic N, and nitrogen oxide, which stem from the IL-driven carbonaceous layer. To corroborate this, the IL-driven carbonaceous layer-coated CNTs were annealed at 800 °C without Pt impregnation (denoted as CNT_IL-800). Indeed, the XPS spectrum of CNT_IL-800 (
Figure
2
d) was very similar to that of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800, except for the absence of the Pt–N
x
peak. Comparing the N 1s XPS spectra of the four Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts (
Figure S4a and Table S3
), the peak position corresponding to the Pt–N
x
species gradually shifted from 399.0 to 399.4 eV as the annealing temperature increased. On the other hand, the peak position corresponding to Pt–N
x
species in PtTPP at 399.4 eV was preserved in the Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
series regardless of the annealing temperature used (
Figure S4b and Table S4
). Accordingly, Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 have the same Pt–N
x
peak position of 399.4 eV. The Pt 4f and N 1s XPS spectra suggest that, after thermal annealing, the catalysts prepared by both the bottom-up and top-down approaches can generate atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
sites with very similar electronic structures.

The local structure of the Pt–N
4
species and their formation were investigated using extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy. The
k
3
-weighted Pt L
3
-edge EXAFS spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
, Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
, and PtTPP (
Figure
3
a) exhibited a major peak at 1.6 Å, which can be assigned to Pt–N or Pt–C scattering (Pt–N/C). All of these catalysts showed a second peak at 2.6 Å, which is due to Pt···C scattering by way of N/C in the first shell.
(38)
The EXAFS spectrum of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp presented a high-intensity peak at 2.0 Å corresponding to Pt–Cl scattering, along with a low-intensity Pt–N/C peak. Hence, high-temperature annealing induced the formation of Pt–N/C bonding at the expense of Pt–Cl bonding in the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts. Notably, both the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts showed no peaks for Pt–Pt EXAFS scattering, which was observed in the EXAFS spectra of PtNP/CNT and Pt foil with the peak at 2.7 Å. To quantify the coordination structure of each shell, we fitted the EXAFS spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
, Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
, and Pt reference (
Figures S5–S7 and Tables S5–S6
). Interestingly, the first Pt–N shells of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 were fitted with the same coordination number (CN) of 3.8 and an interatomic distance of 2.01 Å. The second Pt···C shell was also fitted with a similar value. We note that the Pt···C shell in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 shows a higher error range for the Debye–Waller factor than that of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-700, which may originate from the presence of an amorphous carbonaceous layer in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800. The EXAFS fitting results for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp and Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
(
Table S5
) suggest an overall trend of increased CN for the Pt–N and Pt···C scattering and decreased CN for the Pt–Cl scattering upon increasing the annealing temperature. On the other hand, the EXAFS fitting of PtTPP and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
(
Table S6
) indicates that the Pt–N
4
center of PtTPP remains intact even after high-temperature annealing, which can be explained by the van Veen model for the thermal implantation of Fe–N
4
sites.
(39)

div.p:
Figure 3. (a)
k
3
-weighted Pt L
3
-edge EXAFS spectra and (b) Pt L
3
-edge XANES spectra for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
, Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
series, PtTPP precursor, PtNP/CNT, and Pt foil.

div.div:
The electronic structure of Pt in the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts can be determined from their X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra (
Figure
3
b). The XANES spectrum of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-imp showed a white line (WL) peak at 11 567 eV and an additional peak at 11 578 eV, which is known as a spectral feature for the H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O precursor.
(40,41)
Upon high-temperature annealing, all of the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts exhibited a slightly positive shift in the WL peak to 11 568 eV, which is consistent with the XPS results. In addition, Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
prepared at an annealing temperature of ≥600 °C exhibited a shoulder peak at 11 574 eV. Interestingly, the XANES spectra of PtTPP and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
also showed nearly identical spectral shapes and WL peak positions (11 568 eV) to those of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
.

Overall, TEM, XPS, EXAFS, and XANES analyses of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
consistently reveal that the bottom-up method using H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O and the top-down approach exploiting PtTPP can generate the Pt–N
4
sites with very similar geometric and electronic structures.

div.h3:
Electrochemical CER Performance of Pt–N
4
Sites
div.div:
Next, we explored the electrocatalytic properties of the prepared catalysts for the CER using a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) technique
(42)
at RT (∼23 °C) and a rotation speed of 1600 rpm. All CER measurements were conducted in a two-compartment H-type cell separated by a Nafion membrane to avoid mixing of the cathodic and anodic products. To compare electrode potentials on the RHE scale, the CER activity was measured in the 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte with 1.0 M of NaCl (
E
CER
= 1.355 V) to minimize the potential deviation from the standard electrode potential of the CER (
E
CER
0
= 1.36 V vs SHE, see
Materials and Methods
). All potentials are given on the RHE scale unless otherwise noted. The CER polarization curves of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts (
Figure
4
a,b) clearly indicate that the CER activity increased with the annealing temperature. Among the series of catalysts studied, Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 showed the best activity. To reach a current density of 10 mA cm
–2
, Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 required an applied overpotential (η) of 40 mV, which is slightly lower than that of Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 (η = 50 mV). With increasing electrode potential, the activity gap between the two catalysts is enhanced. We note that the polarization curves of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 in the absence of Cl
–
exhibited a nearly negligible current, indicating that the current from the catalysts originates from the CER only. The CNT_IL-800 without Pt sites also showed a very low current density, suggesting that the CER current density was almost exclusively generated due to the presence of the Pt–N
4
sites.

div.p:
Figure 4. CER polarization curves of (a) Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and (b) Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts in 1.0 M NaCl + 0.1 M HClO
4
. (c) CER selectivity of Pt
1

4
measured by iodometric titration and the RRDE method corresponding to
Figure S8
.

div.div:
The comparison of the polarization curves of the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts suggests that the activity trends of the two catalyst sets are different. For the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts, the CER activity of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-500 was very low and comparable to that of CNT_IL-800. The CER activity of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
increased substantially after annealing at 600 and 700 °C, and further increased to show maximum activity after annealing at 800 °C. Interestingly, this enhancement in the CER activity after annealing over 600 °C can be correlated to the evolution of the XANES peak at 11 574 eV observed in the Pt L
3
-edge XANES spectra (
Figure
3
b). For the Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
series, even low-temperature annealing at 500 °C was sufficient to exhibit a considerable CER activity due to the presence of Pt–N
4
sites. Annealing at 600 and 700 °C gradually enhanced the CER activity, which was almost saturated at 700 °C. These findings suggest that the high-temperature annealing step is imperative to endow high CER activity to the two series of Pt–N/C catalysts, but its impact differs according to the synthetic strategy.

For the CER, the electrochemical selectivity is another critical parameter because of the competitive nature between the CER and the OER. We measured the electrochemical CER selectivity using iodometric titration and RRDE chronoamperometry in 0.1 M NaCl + 0.1 M HClO
4
(
Figure
4
c).
(42)
The iodometric titration of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 revealed 96 ± 1.2 and 97 ± 0.7% CER selectivity at 10 mA cm
–2
, respectively (
Figure S8a,b
), and similar selectivities were also obtained using the RRDE method (100 ± 0.5 and 94 ± 1.6%,
Figure S8c,d
). In contrast, DSA exhibited low CER selectivity of 61% in the same electrolyte.
(31)
In summary, both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 bearing Pt–N
4
active sites showed similar activity and selectivity trends for the CER. Further discussion of the CER kinetics and mechanism for these two electrocatalysts are given below.

div.h3:
Electrochemical CER Kinetics on Pt–N
4
Sites
div.div:
We then extensively explored the CER kinetics of the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 catalysts. The CER proceeds via a 2e
–
transfer pathway, which can be commonly described using three elementary reaction steps: (i) Volmer, (ii) Heyrovský or Krishtalik, and (iii) Tafel (
eqs 1
–
5
).
(43,44)
The Volmer step is the electrochemical adsorption and discharge of a chloride ion on the electrocatalyst active site (S); the Heyrovský step refers to the recombination of the S–Cl
ads
species with a Cl
–
ion from the bulk electrolyte to generate Cl
2
; the Krishtalik step corresponds to the formation of a chloronium (S–Cl
ads
+
) intermediate, which also recombines with a Cl
–
ion from the electrolyte to form Cl
2
; and the Tafel step is the recombination of two adjacent adsorbed chlorine species (S–Cl
ads
) to generate Cl
2
.
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
(5)

The Tafel step is unlikely to occur on the Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 catalysts because the atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
sites are isolated from each other. The Krishtalik step can also be ruled out for the Pt–N
4
sites due to the absence of an electron-rich oxide lattice to stabilize the S–Cl
ads
+
intermediate.
(43)
Consequently, the probable elementary reactions on the Pt
1
/CNT catalysts are the Volmer and Heyrovský steps. If the rate-determining step (RDS) is the Volmer or Heyrovský step, a Tafel slope (
b
) of 40 or 120 mV dec
–1
, respectively, is conventionally predicted using the Tafel approximation of
eq 6
.
(6)
where
j
and
j
0
represent the measured current density and exchange current density, respectively. For many electrochemical reactions, the Tafel slope serves as an important parameter to compare the electrocatalytic activity of different electrode materials. For 2e
–
-transfer reactions such as the CER, however,
eq 6
represents the simplest kinetic equation, which is derived by the quasi-equilibrium assumption in that it is tacitly assumed that the reaction commences from the electrocatalyst active site (S). Yet, the quasi-equilibrium approximation does not take the surface coverage of reaction intermediates into account, thereby emphasizing that surface coverages are strongly depending on the applied electrode potential. For instance, in the classical Tafel analysis, the Tafel slope of 40 mV dec
−1
corresponds to the Heyrovský step as the RDS since the coverage of the intermediate S–Cl
ads
is considered to be negligible. However, in case the criterion of a negligible S–Cl
ads
coverage is violated, a Tafel slope of 40 mV dec
−1
is related to the Volmer step rather than the Heyrovský step as the RDS, since the reaction mechanism commences from S–Cl
ads
rather than S. Therefore, we examine the potential-dependent coverage of the S–Cl
ads
precursor to resolve the reaction mechanism of the CER over Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 unambiguously.

To determine the potential-dependent coverage of S–Cl
ads
, we analyzed the reaction kinetics of the CER using the theoretical model proposed by Tilak and Conway,
(46)
in which the Tafel slope and reaction order (
) are dependent on the coverage of the S–Cl
ads
species (θ
Cl
). In the Tilak and Conway model, the lateral interaction between the S–Cl
ads
species is considered to reflect more realistic reaction conditions, which, however, can be fairly excluded for atomically dispersed catalysts because of the isolated geometry of the active sites. For the Volmer–Heyrovský mechanism (
Figure
5
a) with a slow Heyrovský as the RDS, θ
Cl
is sufficiently high so that the S–Cl
ads
species is in the quasi-equilibrium state.
(45−47)
Because the fast Volmer step is pre-equilibrated for the slow Heyrovský step, θ
Cl
can serve as the sole parameter to describe the reaction kinetics, and the
b
and
values can be calculated using the following
eqs 7
and
8
.
(7)
(8)
where
R
,
T
,
F
, β, and [Cl
–
] are the gas constant (8.314 J K
–1
mol
–1
), temperature (K), Faraday constant, symmetry factor for charge transfer in the RDS (generally 0.5),
(47)
and concentration of Cl
–
in the electrolyte, respectively. For the CER over metal oxide catalysts, especially Ru and Ir oxides, the quasi-equilibrium conditions of the S–Cl
ads
and Heyrovský RDS have been widely accepted.
(15,21,47)

div.p:
Figure 5. Proposed CER mechanisms over the atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
sites for (a) the Volmer–Heyrovský (V–H) mechanism with S–Cl
ads
in quasi-equilibrium conditions and (b) the Heyrovský–Volmer (H–V) mechanism with S–Cl
ads
in steady-state conditions.

div.div:
On the other hand, if the CER is governed by the Volmer step as the RDS, a steady state of low θ
Cl
is expected (
Figure
5
b),
(46,48,49)
where the slow Cl
–
adsorption of the Volmer step cannot supply enough θ
Cl
for the rapid generation of Cl
2
via the Heyrovský step. Under this condition, the rate constant of the Heyrovský step is too high to be neglected,
(46,49)
and thus, the rate constants for both elementary steps should be considered, along with θ
Cl
as presented in the following
eqs 9
and
10
.
(9)
(10)
where
k
V
and
k
H
indicate the forward rate constants of Volmer and Heyrovský steps, respectively. In our previous work,
(31)
we proposed using computational methods that the Volmer step governs the RDS at low η (≤90 mV) for the Pt–N
4
sites, based on the free-energy diagram developed by Exner et al.
(50,51)

In this study, we experimentally determined the reaction orders for the CER on Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, for which the CER activities were measured as a function of [Cl
–
] (
Figure
6
a,b). For a fair comparison, the electrolytes were prepared with a constant ionic strength and the pH of the electrolyte was fixed at 0.9 ± 0.5. Both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 exhibited a [Cl
–
]-dependent shift in their CER polarization curves. This behavior can be explained using the Nernst equation for the CER, which indicates that the equilibrium potential of the CER (
E
CER
) shifts according to [Cl
–
] (see
Materials and Methods
for details). Comparing the [Cl
–
]-dependent
E
CER
, similar current densities were observed at η = 30 mV (η
30
,
Figure S9
). When the CER polarization curves were plotted following
eq 10
(log
j
vs log [Cl
–
] plots,
Figure
6
c,d), both catalysts exhibited good linearity. At a fixed potential of 1.41 V (η = 55 mV), the reaction orders were calculated to be 1.82 and 1.78 for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, respectively. A reaction order approaching two can be obtained for the metal oxide catalysts in an acidic electrolyte at [Cl
–
] ≤ 0.1 M.
(21,52)
However, when [Cl
–
] exceeds 0.1 M, a reaction order close to 2 is anomalous and unobservable with metal oxide catalysts that commonly show a reaction order of 1 with the Heyrovský step as the RDS.
(21,52)
Indeed, PtNP/CNT, where the Pt NPs transform into Pt oxide under oxidative conditions, exhibited an
value of 1.11 at 1.44 V (
Figure S10a,b
). The
of ∼2 exhibited by both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 at 1.41 V is in accordance with the steady-state description of
eq 10
, which predicts
close to 2 for small
θ
Cl
, and thus the reaction is governed by the Volmer step as the RDS. When the applied potential was increased,
values of the two Pt–N/C catalysts decreased gradually (
Figure
6
c,d), suggesting that the RDS may switch from the Volmer to Heyrovský step.

Figure 6. CER polarization curves of (a) Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and (b) Pt
1

4
with different NaCl concentrations. log

–
] plots of (c) Pt

div.div:
We note that such an interpretation of the change in the reaction order is valid only if the pH of the electrolyte does not affect the activity. In turn, we monitored the effect of the proton concentration on the CER activity over the Pt–N
4
sites by changing the HClO
4
concentration. The decrease in the HClO
4
concentration was compensated for by adding NaClO
4
to maintain the ionic strength of the electrolyte. Due to the pH change, the applied potential was converted to the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) scale (
E
NHE
=
E
Ag/AgCl
+ 0.197 V). The reaction order of the proton concentration was determined using
eq 10
by exchanging [Cl
–
] with [H
+
]. The calculated results revealed a nearly zero order with poor linearity for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800, Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, and PtNP/CNT (
Figures
6
e,f and
S10c
), indicating that the proton concentration exerts a minimal effect on the CER over the Pt–N/C catalysts under acidic conditions.

Next, [Cl
–
]-dependent Tafel slopes of the Pt
1
/CNT catalysts were analyzed. The Tafel slopes of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 calculated by Tafel equation (
eq 6
) were almost independent of [Cl
–
] and ranged between 35 and 42 mV dec
–1
with average values of 37 and 41 mV dec
–1
, respectively (see insets of
Figure
6
a,b). The Tafel slopes of PtNP/CNT were also independent of [Cl
–
] and averaged 66 mV dec
–1
(
Figure S10d
). We note that the Tafel slope can also be obtained using
eqs 9
and
10
under the steady-state conditions. This
-derived Tafel slope is completely different from the traditional Tafel slopes derived from
eq 6
using independent polarization curves. If these two approaches provide similar Tafel slopes, one can suggest that the CER kinetics of the catalyst is well described by the steady-state approximation. The
values provided the Tafel slope of 45 and 46 mV dec
–1
at 1.41 V for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, respectively (
Figure
6
c,d). These Tafel slopes are close to those from the experimental polarization curves (around 40 mV dec
–1
), suggesting the suitability of the steady-state approximation to the low η region for Pt
1
/CNT catalysts. Moreover, the Tafel slopes increase at higher overpotential, confirming the switch of the RDS. Interestingly, for the PtNP/CNT, the
-derived Tafel slope values were 97 mV dec
–1
at 1.44 V and 203 mV dec
–1
at 1.48 V (
Figure S10b
), which are markedly different from the experimental Tafel slope of 66 mV dec
–1
, indicating that steady-state approximation was inappropriate to explain the CER kinetics on Pt oxides. The kinetics of the PtNP/CNT are consistent with our previous results, which suggested that the CER on Pt oxides at low η is governed by the quasi-equilibrium approximation and the Heyrovský step as the RDS.
(21,47,52,53)

In addition, by merging
eqs 9
and
10
, the θ
Cl
and
k
H
/
k
V
values for the CER can be correlated using
eq 11
.
(11)
The ratio of
k
V
and
k
H
was then plotted as a function of θ
Cl
at a given potential (
Figure S11
). These plots indicate that, excluding the area of invalid θ
Cl
with negative
k
V
/
k
H
ratios, θ
Cl
during the CER at 1.41 V cannot exceed 0.18 and 0.3 for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, respectively. The low θ
Cl
may suggest the Volmer step as the RDS of the CER over the Pt–N
4
sites, where the Heyrovský step proceeds much faster than the Volmer step. In addition, the limit of the θ
Cl
values increased with increasing potential, which can be linked to the decrease in the reaction order with increased potential. We note that Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 exhibited a slower increase in the coverage limit compared to Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, which may account for the greater CER activity of the former at higher overpotentials (
Figure
4
a,b). The Tafel analyses with different approximations and potential-dependent θ
Cl
provide strong evidence that the CER over Pt–N
4
sites complies with the steady-state approximation at low η, unlike the CER over Pt oxides following the quasi-equilibrium assumption.

In addition, we also investigated the CER mechanism over the Pt–N
4
sites using the method developed by Ferro and De Battisti.
(53)
In their approach, a test plot is generated by reordering the CER polarization curves, which is thought to exhibit linear correlation for catalysts that are governed by the Heyrovský step as the RDS, such as IrO
2
and RuO
2
(
Figure S12
).
(21,54)
However, in the range of low η (0–90 mV), neither Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 nor Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 displayed good linearity and exhibited negative
y
-intercepts in the test plot, indicating that the CER on Pt–N
4
sites cannot be governed by the Heyrovský step.

A recent theoretical study using the free-energy diagram as a descriptor also predicted the switching of the reaction mechanism with the introduction of a threshold potential (
E
thld
), where the change in the RDS takes place when η overcomes the thermodynamic optimum of the active sites.
(50,51,55)
In our previous work,
(31)
we reported that the
E
thld
for the switch of the RDS from the Volmer step (low η) to the Heyrovský step (high η) was ∼1.45 V (η = 95 mV). As shown in
Figure S13
, Tafel plots of both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 in 1.0 M NaCl + 0.1 M HClO
4
showed the
E
thld
values between 1.42 V (η = 65 mV) and 1.445 V (η = 90 mV), which are close to our previous theoretical prediction.
(31)
The
E
thld
divides two Tafel regions of low η (∼40 mV dec
–1
) and high η (∼140 mV dec
–1
), providing the experimental evidence for the potential-dependent switching of the RDS, which is in qualitative agreement with the coverage analysis (
vide supra
).

Although Tafel plots can provide the
E
thld
values and approximate Tafel slopes at high η, the reaction order and the corresponding θ
Cl
above 1.44 V (high η) are hard to be calculated accurately due to two practical limitations: (i) At high [Cl
–
], a large amount of Cl
2
gas evolves that can block the electrode surface, which consequently leads to incorrect current measurements,
(33)
and (ii) at low [Cl
–
], the CER is governed by mass-transfer limitations at high η (
Figure
6
a,b), in that the quasi-equilibrium or steady-state descriptions cannot be guaranteed because the surface concentration of Cl
–
becomes limited and unequal to the bulk concentration.
(48)
Therefore, we opted to use in situ electrochemical XANES to further verify the applied potential-dependent changes of the coverage, θ
Cl
, and the CER mechanism.

div.h3: In Situ Electrochemical XANES for CER in Acidic Media
div.div:
In situ electrochemical XANES spectra can provide valuable information on the redox behavior of active sites during electrocatalytic reactions. Specifically, the WL intensity of in situ XANES spectra reveals the changes in the relative oxidation state of the active site.
(56−59)
Under the CER conditions of 1.0 NaCl + 0.1 M HClO
4
, the in situ electrochemical Pt L
3
-edge XANES spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 (
Figures
7
a and
S14a,b
) and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 (
Figures
7
b and
S14c,d
) were recorded upon ascending and subsequently descending the potential (
iR
-uncompensated). Quantitative analyses of their WL intensity were carried out by fitting the XANES spectra with the combination of a Gaussian function (WL response) and an arctangent function (edge-jump baseline).
(58−60)
The average oxidation number of Pt can be calculated by integrating an area of a Gaussian function at 11 568 eV (WL peak) and interpolating the resulting value into those of Pt references with well-known oxidation numbers (e.g., K
2
PtCl
4
for Pt
2+
and H
2
PtCl
6
for Pt
4+
) (
Figure S15
). In
Figure
7
c, similar changes in the oxidation number of active sites under CER and OER conditions were observed in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700, indicating that they undergo similar chemical changes during the CER. Before all in situ measurements were carried out, the ex situ XANES spectra of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 (
Figure S16
) and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 (
Figure S17
) were recorded, and the oxidation number of 2 was confirmed for both catalysts (
Figure S15c
). Immediately after immersing the catalyst in the electrolyte at an open-circuit potential (OCP), the WL intensity at 11 568 eV increased, giving rise to an average oxidation number of 2.2, presumably due to the slight oxidation of the catalysts in the aqueous acidic electrolyte. This phenomenon was also observed even without NaCl in the electrolyte (
Figures S18–S21
). Interestingly, the average oxidation number further increased to ∼2.4 upon increasing the applied potential to 1.10 V and remained nearly the same at 1.25 V, which is lower than the
E
CER
(1.355 V). This anomalous phenomenon can be understood using the Pourbaix diagram of Pt–N
4
species in our previous result,
(31)
which suggests the preadsorption of Cl
–
below
E
CER
because Cl* is thermodynamically the most stable species in pH 1 with 1.0 M Cl
–
. When the potential was increased to 1.4 V (η = 45 mV), the average oxidation number increased to ∼2.8, which is induced by the catalysis of the CER. At the potential of 1.55 V (η = 195 mV), the average oxidation number was further increased to ∼3.9. Notably, the oxidation number gap between 1.40 and 1.55 V is much greater than that between 1.25 and 1.40 V. Because the CER is a simple 2e
–
-transfer reaction with a single reaction intermediate, the changes in the average oxidation number can be correlated to the coverage difference, especially for the atomically dispersed active site. With an assumption of the fully covered S–Cl
ads
intermediates (θ
Cl
= 1) possessing the oxidation number of 4, at a low η of 45 mV, a low θ
Cl
value of ∼0.4 is expected, where the Volmer RDS governs the CER mechanism. This is also close to the 0.2–0.3 of low θ
Cl
obtained from the reaction order analyses (
Figure S11
). At a high η of 195 mV, Pt–N
4
active sites are additionally occupied by S–Cl
ads
species suggesting that the desorption step is stagnated, invoking the switch of the RDS to the Heyrovský step. When the potential was subsequently decreased to 1.40 V, the average oxidation number returned reversibly to ∼2.8. The WL intensity and the average oxidation number of ∼ 2.8 remained almost constant even after a further decrease in the potential (
Figure
7
). Such changes may originate from the presence of residual S–Cl
ads
after the CER with a slow adsorption step, providing strong evidence of the Volmer RDS at low η. The oxidation number obtained without NaCl (OER condition) remained nearly the same from open-circuit potential (OCP) to 1.40 V for both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 (
Figure
7
c), indicating that Pt–N
4
is inactive for the OER. Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 only exhibited a slight increase in the oxidation number at 1.55 V and during the potential-descending step, presumably due to the presence of IL-derived carbonaceous layer of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800. We suppose that the electrochemical vulnerability of the carbonaceous layer in Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 could lead to carbon dissolution under oxidative potential during the OER,
(60)
invoking the facile oxidation of Pt species. This increase was not observed in Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 without the carbonaceous layer (
Figures
7
c and
S18
).

div.p:
Figure 7. In situ electrochemical Pt L
3
-edge XANES spectra in 1.0 M NaCl + 0.1 M HClO
4
for (a) Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and (b) Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700. (c) Average oxidation number of atomically dispersed Pt sites calculated by WL area integration as a function of applied potentials (see
Figures S16, S17, S19, and S20
).

div.div:
By combining the analyses of the reaction kinetics and potential-dependent in situ electrochemical XANES spectra with previous theoretical prediction,
(31)
the changes in the θ
Cl
, schematic free-energy diagram, and RDS during the CER are presented in
Figure
8
. According to the in situ XANES analysis below
E
CER
, the preadsorption of Cl
–
renders the Heyrovský step as the first step and the Volmer step as the second step of the CER. At low η below
E
thld
(η = 65–90 mV), the Pt
1
/CNT exhibited the reaction order of ∼2 and the Tafel slope of ∼40 mV dec
–1
with low θ
Cl
, in which the uncommon Volmer step as the RDS is expected. However, as the potential is increased beyond
E
thld
, the Volmer step gradually becomes faster than the Heyrovský step. Consequently, in the high η region with ∼140 mV dec
–1
of the Tafel slope, θ
Cl
increases and the CER mechanism switches to the Heyrovský step as the RDS. The switch of the RDS measured by electrochemical and physical analyses is also consistent with our previous thermodynamic prediction based on free-energy diagrams.
(31,45)
At resting potentials after the CER, the S–Cl
ads
species still remain on the catalyst surface, indicating stagnant S–Cl
ads
at the Volmer step as the RDS. In addition, the remaining S–Cl
ads
species have a strong affinity between the Pt–N
4
sites and Cl
–
, which can explain the high CER activity and selectivity of Pt–N/C catalysts.

div.p: Figure 8. Visualization of the switching of proposed CER mechanisms over Pt–N/C catalysts by summarizing the kinetic analyses, in situ electrochemical XANES, and schematic free-energy diagrams.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We have demonstrated the generality of Pt–N
4
active sites to catalyze the CER with high activity and selectivity using Pt
1
/CNT catalysts prepared from bottom-up and top-down approaches. Both Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-800 and Pt
1
/CNT(P)-700 exhibited similarly high CER activities and selectivities in acidic media. Kinetic analyses and in situ electrochemical XANES spectroscopy revealed that the atomically dispersed Pt–N
4
sites exhibit unique potential-dependent switching of the reaction order and reaction mechanism during the CER. At low overpotentials (η = 65–90 mV), the surface coverage, θ
Cl
, is small, the reaction order in chloride of the Pt
1
/CNT catalysts is close to two, and the Volmer step is identified as the RDS. In the high overpotential regime (η > 140 mV), the coverage θ
Cl
increases, the reaction order in chloride decreases, and thus the Heyrovský step becomes the RDS. We are confident that this work provides fundamental insights into the CER catalyzed by atomically dispersed CER catalysts, which show a different reaction kinetics and an unusual potential-dependent switch in the RDS compared to mixed metal oxide-based catalysts that have dominated the CER during the last half-century.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Sodium chloride (NaCl, ≥99%), sodium iodide (NaI, anhydrous, ≥99.5%), and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][TFSI], 98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Multiwalled carbon nanotubes (CNT, MR99, average diameter, 10 nm; average length, 10 μm) were purchased from Carbon Nano-material Technology Co. Prior to use, the CNT was purified by thermal annealing and acid treatment to remove metallic impurities according to a reported procedure.
(61,62)
Nitric acid (HNO
3
, 60%), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36%), ethanol (94.5%), acetone (99.5%), and anhydrous ethanol (99.9%) were purchased from Samchun Chemicals. Perchloric acid (HClO
4
, 70%, Veritas double-distilled) was purchased from GFS Chemicals. Hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
, 30%) was purchased from Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd. Sodium perchlorate monohydrate (NaClO
4
·H
2
O, >97%), standardized sodium thiosulfate solution (Na
2
S
2
O
3
, 0.01 N), and soluble starch powder (ACS grade, for iodometry) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. Pt(II) meso-tetraphenylporphine (PtTPP, >95%) was purchased from Frontier Scientific. Dihydrogen hexachloroplatinate(IV) hydrate (H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O, 99.95%) was purchased from Umicore. All chemicals were used without further purification, except for the CNT.

The ionic liquid-coated CNT (CNT_IL) was synthesized following a literature procedure.
(34)
To prepare a series of Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
(
X
= annealing temperature) catalysts, 0.032 g of H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O was dissolved in 2 mL of acetone. The precursor solution was mixed with 0.388 g of CNT_IL in a plastic bag upon hand scrubbing. The dried mixture was placed in an alumina crucible and annealed at the desired temperature between 500 and 800 °C for 3 h (ramping rate, 2.1 °C min
–1
) under a flow of 1 L min
–1
N
2
(99.999%). To prepare a series of Pt
1
/CNT(P)-
X
catalysts, 0.500 g of CNT and 0.071 g of PtTPP were ground in an agate mortar until the color and texture did not change (∼20 min).
(31)
The mixture was heated using the same annealing step used for Pt
1
/CNT(Cl)-
X
catalysts. To prepare the PtNP/CNT, 0.044 of H
2
PtCl
6
·6H
2
O was dissolved in 5.4 mL of acetone. The solution was mixed with 0.5 g of CNT in a plastic bag upon hand scrubbing. The dried powder was annealed at 200 °C under a flow of 0.5 L min
–1
H
2
(99.999%) for 2 h (ramping rate, 0.6 °C min
–1
). Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 350 °C (ramping rate, 2.5 °C min
–1
) under a flow of 1.0 L min
–1
N
2
(99.999%) and maintained at that temperature for 3 h.

High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images were taken using a Titan
3
G2 60-300 microscope (FEI Company) equipped with a double-sided spherical aberration (Cs) corrector operating at an accelerating voltage of 80 and 200 kV, respectively. X-ray diffraction patterns were taken with a high-power X-ray diffractometer (D/MAX2500V/PC, Rigaku) equipped with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 200 mA. XRD patterns were measured in the 2θ range from 10 to 90° and from 30 to 50° at a scan rate of 2 and 0.5° min
–1
, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a K-Alpha spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific), equipped with a monochromatic Al K-α X-ray source (1486.6 eV). Pt 4f and N 1s XPS peak deconvolution was carried out to fit the curve using XPSPeak41 software with a mixed Gaussian (70)–Lorentzian (30) function after a Shirley-type background correction. The spin–orbit components of Pt 4f XPS were fixed at 3.34 eV. To quantify the amount of Pt in the catalysts, a microwave digestion system (Mars 6, CEM) was used to completely dissolve the Pt in aqua regia (36% HCl:60% HNO
3
= 3:1, v-v) at 220 °C for 40 min (600 W; ramping rate, 6.7 °C min
–1
). Subsequently, the resulting solution was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP–OES) on a 700-ES, Varian analyzer. The carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen contents in the samples were determined using a combustion elemental analyzer (EA, Flash 2000, Thermo Fisher Scientific).

Pt L
3
-edge XAS spectra were collected at RT at the 6D, 8C, and 10C beamlines of the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL). The storage ring was operated at 3.0 GeV with a beam current of 300 mA in the decay mode. The beamline was equipped with a focusing Si(1 1 1) double-crystal monochromator, which was used to filter the incident photons. The X-ray was detuned by 20% to remove high-order harmonics and was calibrated using a standard Pt foil. X-ray intensities were monitored using standard N
2
-filled ion chambers and an Ar-filled detector. The catalyst powder was pelletized in a sample holder (1 cm in width) to an adequate thickness to obtain a significant transmission signal. Background removal and normalization of the absorption coefficient for XANES spectra and fitting for the Fourier transformed
k
3
-weighted EXAFS spectra were carried out using Athena and Artemis software
(63)
with 1.1 of
R
bkg
in a Hanning-type window. Crystallographic data of the PtTPP molecule were used for multishell fitting with the first shell of Pt–N and the second shell of Pt···C.
(64)
Throughout the fitting analysis, the amplitude reduction factor (
S
0
2
) of Pt was fixed at 0.83, which was obtained by fitting the EXAFS spectrum of a standard Pt foil.

In situ electrochemical Pt L
3
-edge XAS spectra were measured at RT in the 8C beamline of PAL. A homemade Teflon spectroelectrochemical cell was used for in situ electrochemical XAS analysis. A catalyst ink was deposited onto the tip of a carbon paper strip (1.0 cm × 1.5 cm) to control the catalyst loading at 2 mg cm
–2
. The as-deposited film was attached to the window of the cell, with the catalyst layer facing the cell and in contact with the electrolyte. Subsequently, the window was fully blocked using Kapton tape and the cell was filled with the 0.1 M HClO
4
+ 1.0 M NaCl electrolyte. The electrolyte was sparged with Ar gas (99.999%) for at least 10 min. A three-electrode system was built using a graphite rod and KCl-saturated Ag/AgCl with a double junction as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. XAS spectra were obtained after applying an open-circuit potential (OCP) for 10 min using the fluorescence detection mode. XAS measurements were conducted with ascending and sequentially descending constant potentials ranging from 1.1 to 1.55 V vs RHE (without
iR
compensation). The experiments were repeated under the OER conditions using a 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte.

The standard reduction potential (

On the other hand, the reverse is applied to the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) relying on the RHE. In this work, the Ag/AgCl reference electrode was experimentally calibrated to the RHE scale in an acidic environment and denoted as

E

of the CER is sensitive to temperature, implying that

The equilibrium potential of the CER (

CER

and

A three-electrode electrochemical system was built using a CHI760E potentiostat (CH Instruments). An E7 rotation ring-disk electrode (RRDE, AFE7R9GCPT, Pine Research Instrumentation, collection efficiency of 0.37), a KCl-saturated Ag/AgCl electrode (RE-1B, ALS Co.) with a double junction, and Pt mesh (2.5 × 2.5 cm, 0.34 mm-thick threads, Alfa Aesar) were used as the working, reference, and counter electrode, respectively. The electrolytes were prepared upon dilution of 70% HClO
4
with 18.2 MΩ cm Millipore water. The pH values of all electrolytes were adjusted by adding 70% HClO
4
or 2 M NaOH and measured using a digital pH meter (Orion A211, Thermo Fischer Scientific). The Ag/AgCl reference electrode was calibrated with respect to the RHE prior to each electrochemical experiment. The RHE conversion was achieved using a two-electrode setup built using a Pt mesh and a reference electrode with continuous H
2
bubbling in the electrolyte, which was used for the measurement of the CER. Pt mesh serves as the RHE because the H
+
/H
2
equilibrium was established. All potentials were presented on the RHE scale unless otherwise noted. An OCP was recorded for 30 min to obtain a stable potential, which was used as the conversion value. All of the CER measurements were conducted using the RRDE to minimize the interference of Cl
2
bubbles on the catalyst surface.
(42)
A MSR rotator (AFMSRCE, Pine Research Instrumentation) was equipped to control the rotation speed of the RRDE. The RRDE was polished on a microcloth using an aqueous 1.0 μm alumina suspension, followed by a 0.3 μm suspension to obtain a mirror finish prior to every measurement. The catalyst ink was prepared using 2.5 mg of catalyst, 50 μL of DI water, 20 μL of 5% Nafion ionomer (D521, DuPont), and 530 μL of anhydrous ethanol, which was sonicated in an ultrasonic bath (Branson) for at least 40 min. The 6 μL of the catalyst ink was deposited onto a glassy carbon (GC) disk (5.61 mm in diameter) of the RRDE using a micropipette (0.5–10 μL, Eppendorf) and subsequently dried at 60 °C for 2 min. The resulting catalyst loading was 0.1 mg cm
–2
. Prior to measuring the CER, the catalyst film was immersed in an Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
. Cyclic voltammetry was conducted to clean and make the catalyst fully wet at a scan rate of 500 mV s
–1
for 50 cycles between 0.05 and 1.2 V. For the RRDE method, the polycrystalline Pt ring electrode (outer diameter = 7.92 mm and inner diameter = 6.25 mm) was cleaned for 20 cycles between 0.05 and 1.4 V at a scan rate of 500 mV s
–1
at 1600 rpm. All electrochemical measurements were independently performed in triplicate, and the average values were presented.

An H-type cell was used to measure the CER to prevent mixing of the cathodic and anodic products. Each compartment in the H-type cell was separated using a Nafion NRE 211 polymer membrane (DuPont). Prior to assembly, the Nafion membrane was heated at 60 °C in 5% H
2
O
2
for 1 h and subsequently cleaned with DI water at 60 °C for 1 h. The electrolytes were prepared by diluting 70% HClO
4
and 99% NaCl with 18.2 MΩ cm Millipore water. For experiments performed under different NaCl concentrations and pH, NaClO
4
·H
2
O was added into the electrolyte to compensate for the total ionic strength.
(23)
The activity of the CER was measured in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
with controlled concentrations of NaCl. Prior to measuring the CER activity, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted at a fixed potential of 0.9 V without
iR
compensation from 100 000 Hz to 1 Hz with a potential amplitude of 10 mV at an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm. In a Bode plot, the solution resistance was determined as the magnitude of the impedance, which was closest to zero. The
iR
compensated potentials (
E
–
iR
) indicate that the potential was corrected to 85% of the measured solution resistance. CVs were conducted from 1.0 to 1.6 V at a scan rate of 10 mV s
–1
with an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm. Five sequential CVs of the CER were conducted to obtain a stable catalyst performance. The forward scan of the 5th CV cycle was used to obtain the representative CER polarization curve.

The Cl
2

A review. Invasive aquatic species discharged through ballast water is one of the most serious problems posed nowadays in the marine environment. This review paper summarizes the available technologies applied for ballast water treatment. These technologies can be either port-based or ship-based, with the latter being easier to implement. Special emphasis was given to onboard treatment methods, which can be categorized as phys. sepn., mech. or chem. methods. The efficiency of the methods, as well as the capacity of application and the target microorganisms were compiled and are presented in this review.

Leow, Wan Ru; Lum, Yanwei; Ozden, Adnan; Wang, Yuhang; Nam, Dae-Hyun; Chen, Bin; Wicks, Joshua; Zhuang, Tao-Tao; Li, Fengwang; Sinton, David; Sargent, Edward H.

Chems. manufg. consumes large amts. of energy and is responsible for a substantial portion of global C emissions. Electrochem. systems that produce the desired compds. by using renewable electricity offer a route to lower C emissions in the chems. sector. Ethylene oxide is among the world's most abundantly produced commodity chems. because of its importance in the plastics industry, notably for manufg. polyesters and polyethylene terephthalate. The authors applied an extended heterogeneous:homogeneous interface, using chloride as a redox mediator at the anode, to facilitate the selective partial oxidn. of ethylene to ethylene oxide. The authors achieved current densities of 1 A per square centimeter, faradaic efficiencies of ∼70%, and product specificities of ∼97%. When run at 300 mA per square centimeter for 100 h, the system maintained a 71(±1)% faradaic efficiency throughout.

Cl as a redox mediator allows for the selective oxidn. of ethylene to 2-chloroethanol, which converts to ethylene oxide in alk. aq. electrolyte. This strategy uses abundant saline H2O as an electrolyte and source of O atoms for functionalization. The authors present a mechanistic study of ethylene oxidn. in saline H2O using Co oxide nanoparticle catalysts. Electrochem. kinetic anal. and in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy suggest that the resting state of the catalyst and the rate-detg. step differ for the Cl evolution reaction in the presence and absence of ethylene. In 0.6M NaCl pH 8 electrolyte, which resembles seawater, the av. c.d. was ~ 60 mA/cm2 with a faradaic efficiency of ~ 41% toward ethylene functionalization. The use of synthetic and natural seawater achieved faradaic efficiencies >70%, while the partial current toward the product remained invariant. Further conversion of the initial product 2-chloroethanol into ethylene glycol was also demonstrated. The authors present a broader vision of harnessing saline H2O in electrochem. functionalization of org. mols. and coprodn. of H.

In the first part of this paper, published in the Jan. issue (Hayfield, ibid. 1998, 42(1), 27-33) development work resulting in the first noble metal/oxide coated titanium electrode was described and some of the teething problems encountered were discussed. Here, the story is continued with the further development of paint compns.: platinum-only and platinum/iridium, for coating the electrodes, and their utilization in chlorate, mercury- and diaphragm-type chlor-alkali cells. Later, these coatings were replaced by ones contg. ruthenium dioxide. This part begins with the early platinum paint compns.

A review with 13 refs. is given. The first two parts of this paper on titanium-based electrodes concd. on the development of coatings comprising noble metals and their oxides suitable for use in chloride-bearing electrolytes. This concluding part deals with similar types of electrodes which act as counter electrodes in com. processes where the product is made on the cathode. Many electrolytes in this category involve sulfuric acid, which means that oxygen evolves at the anodes. Applications for which these electrodes are used range from those operating at very high c.d., such as electrogalvanizing, to others at much lower c.d., such as impressed current cathodic protection of rebar in concrete.

A review with 92 refs. concerning dimensionally stable anodes fundamentals and technol. is presented. The "legend" of DSA (Dimensionally Stable Anodes), one of the greatest technol. breakthrough of the past 50 yr of electrochem., is reviewed with the aim to emphasize the reasons for their success. In this respect, the industrial success, which came first, was due to factors differing from those responsible for the successive boom of fundamental research on the same materials. This article scrutinizes these factors highlighting the aspects which make these materials so much intriguing.

A review. Cl gas and Na chlorate are two base chems. produced through electrolysis of NaCl brine which find uses in many areas of industrial chem. Although the industrial prodn. of these chems. started over 100 years ago, there are still factors that limit the energy efficiencies of the processes. This review focuses on the unwanted prodn. of O gas, which decreases the charge yield by up to 5%. Understanding the factors that control the rate of O prodn. requires understanding of both chem. reactions occurring in the electrolyte, as well as surface reactions occurring on the anodes. The dominant anode material used in chlorate and chlor-alkali prodn. is the dimensionally stable anode (DSA), Ti coated by a mixed oxide of RuO2 and TiO2. Although the selectivity for Cl evolution on DSA is high, the fundamental reasons for this high selectivity are just now becoming elucidated. This review summarizes the research, since the early 1900s until today, concerning the selectivity between Cl and O evolution in chlorate and chlor-alkali prodn. It covers exptl. as well as theor. studies and highlights the relations between process conditions, electrolyte compn., the material properties of the anode, and the selectivity for O formation.

The faradaic selectivity of the Cl evolution reaction (CER) and O evolution reaction (OER) on the industrially important Ti-Ru-Ir mixed metal oxide is discussed. Abs. evolution rates as well as vol. fractions of Cl2 and O2 were quantified using differential electrochem. mass spectrometry (DEMS), while the catalyst surface redox behavior was analyzed using cyclic voltammetry. The spatial inhomogeneity of the surface catalytic reaction rate was probed using Scanning Electrochem. Microscopy (SECM). Although the nature of the competition between electrochem. discharging of chloride ions and H2O mols. remains elusive on a mol. scale, new insights into the spatial reactivity distribution of the CER and OER were obtained. Oxidn. of H2O is the initial step in corrosion and concomitant deactivation of the oxide electrodes; however, at the same time the nature of interaction between the oxide surface and H2O was used as a rational indicator of selectivity and catalytic activity. An exptl. procedure was established that would allow the study of selectivity of a variety of different catalyst materials using polycryst. electrode surfaces.

This paper summarizes the thermodn. theory of multi-electron transfer reactions and its implications for electrocatalysis. The fundamental differences between catalyzing reactions involving the transfer of one electron or no catalytic intermediates, two electron transfers with one catalytic intermediate, two electron transfer with two catalytic intermediates, and more than two electron transfers with more than one intermediate are discussed. These different classes of reactions imply different optimization problems for finding the best catalyst, dictated primarily by the thermodn. of binding of the catalytic intermediates. The application of this theory to H evolution and oxidn., O evolution and redn., and CO2 redn., is discussed.

Requisites for electrode materials to be suitable for technol. applications are outlined and discussed. Oxides with metallic or quasi-metallic cond. meet these requirements best. Most of these electrodes are prepd. by thermal procedures. The temp. of prepn. affects the catalytic activity through the surface area and the chem. compn. (nonstoichiometry). The covariation of these parameters is best followed in situ by voltammetric curves and point of zero charge measurements. Examples are given for pure RuO2, IrO2, Co3O4 and IrO2 + RuO2 mixts. Kinetic and mechanistic details are discussed for O evolution on RuO2, IrO2 and Co3O4 and for Cl evolution on RuO2 and Co3O4. Finally the electrocatalytic properties of different oxides are correlated with the energy change involved in the lower → higher valency state transition. Exptl. data for both O and Cl evolution can thus be organized into a volcano curve enabling predictive interpolations to be made.

Based on d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. the authors study the electrochem. chlorine evolution reaction on rutile (110) oxide surfaces. First the authors construct the Pourbaix surface diagram for IrO2 and RuO2, and from this the chlorine evolution reaction intermediates and identify the lowest overpotential at which all elementary reaction steps in the chlorine evolution reaction are downhill in free energy were found. This condition is then used as a measure for catalytic activity. Linear scaling relations between the binding energies of the intermediates and the oxygen binding energies at cus-sites are established for MO2 (M being Ir, Ru, Pt, Ti). The linear relations form the basis for constructing a generalized surface phase diagram where 2 parameters, the potential and the binding energy of oxygen, are needed to det. the surface compn. The authors calc. the catalytic activity as function of the oxygen binding energy, giving rise to a Sabatier volcano. By combining the surface phase diagram and the volcano describing the catalytic activity, the reaction mechanism differs depending on catalyst material. The flexibility in reaction path means that the chlorine evolution activity is high for a wide range of oxygen binding energies. The required overpotential for chlorine evolution is lower than the overpotential necessary for oxygen evolution.

In the industrially important Chlor-Alkali process, the chlorine evolution reaction (CER) over a ruthenium dioxide (RuO2) catalyst competes with the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). This selectivity issue is elucidated on the microscopic level with the single-cryst. model electrode RuO2(110) by employing d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. in combination with the concept of volcano plots. We demonstrate that one monolayer of TiO2(110) supported on RuO2(110) enhances the selectivity towards the CER by several orders of magnitudes, while preserving the high activity for the CER. Nanocryst. Mg-doped ruthenium dioxide catalysts with the formula Ru1-xMgxO2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 20) were synthesized by the spray-freezing freeze-drying technique. Synthesized materials are of nanoparticulate nature and show a single phase diffraction pattern conforming to a tetragonal oxide of the rutile structural type. Magnesium ions are not distributed homogeneously in the material, but exist in Mg-rich clusters as shown by X-ray absorption spectroscopy. The refinement of the Mg EXAFS functions for materials with low Mg content shows that the magnesium rich clusters contain Mg in a highly strained environment similar to that of the rutile-type structure. The Mg environment shifts to an ilmenite-type inclusion when Mg occupies more than 10% of all cationic positions. All Mg modified materials are active in oxygen evolution and chlorine evolution reactions. Although the Mg contg. catalysts show lower overall activities compared with the non-doped ruthenia, they feature enhanced selectivity toward the chlorine evolution process, which is attributed primarily to the opening of a reaction pathway for chlorine evolution assocd. with presence of Mg modified active sites.

Current progress in modern electrocatalysis research is spurred by theory, frequently based on ab initio thermodn., where the stable reaction intermediates at the electrode surface are identified, while the actual energy barriers are ignored. This approach is popular in that a simple tool is available for searching for promising electrode materials. However, thermodn. alone may be misleading to assess the catalytic activity of an electrochem. reaction as the authors exemplify with the Cl evolution reaction (CER) over a RuO2(110) model electrode. The full procedure is introduced, starting from the stable reaction intermediates, computing the energy barriers, and finally performing microkinetic simulations, all performed under the influence of the solvent and the electrode potential. Full kinetics from 1st-principles allows the rate-detg. step in the CER to be identified and the exptl. obsd. change in the Tafel slope to be explained.

The electrochem. Cl evolution reaction (CER) and O evolution reaction (OER) represent core processes in the prodn. of Cl, relevant to bulk chem. manufg., and H2O splitting, the most promising technol. for renewable energy storage. Unfortunately, because of an apparent coupling between their key binding intermediates, the two reactions can easily occur simultaneously, which is never an attractive outcome. Using Ir-based double perovskites and rotating ring-disk voltammetry to deconvolute parallel OER and CER currents, the authors explored the interdependence of CER and OER in dil. acidic chloride solns. of up to 120 mM, where both reactions may occur in parallel with similar current densities. The authors also employed online inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurements to probe the material stability and its dependence on chloride concn. For all studied materials, the authors found a strong linear correlation between CER and OER activity as well as a comparable selectivity, strengthening the suggestion that OER and CER follow a scaling relation. Also chloride selectively enhances the dissoln. of the noble metal component. A reaction order anal. was performed to gain insight into the CER mechanism, the effect of surface area changes due to adventitious leaching, and the obsd. suppressing effect of chloride on OER.

The formation of gaseous Cl within chlor-alkali electrolysis is accompanied by a selectivity problem, as the evolution of gaseous O constitutes a detrimental side reaction in the same potential range. As such, the development of electrode materials with high selectivity toward the Cl evolution reaction is of particular importance to the chem. industry. Insight into the elementary reaction steps is ultimately required to comprehend Cl selectivity on a mol. level. Commonly, linear scaling relations are analyzed by the construction of a volcano plot, using the binding energy of O, ΔEO, as a descriptor in the anal. The present article restudies the selectivity problem of the competing Cl and O evolution reactions by applying a different strategy compared to previous literature studies. On the one hand, a unifying material-screening framework that, besides binding energies, also includes the applied overpotential, kinetics, and the electrochem.-step symmetry index was used to comprehend trends in this selectivity issue for transition-metal oxide-based electrodes. However, the free-energy difference between the adsorbed O and adsorbed hydroxide, ΔG2, rather than ΔEO was used as a descriptor in the anal. The formation of the OCl adsorbate within the Cl evolution reaction inherently limits Cl selectivity, whereas, in the optimum case, the formation of the Cl intermediate can result in significantly higher Cl selectivity. This finding was used to derive the design criteria for highly selective Cl evolution electrocatalysts, which can be used in the future to search for potential electrode compns. by material-screening techniques.

The selectivity of the chlorine evolution reaction over the oxygen evolution reaction during the electrolysis of aq. NaCl is, despite being very high, still insufficient to prevent expensive sepn. of the formed Cl2 and O2 by means of liquefaction. We hypothesize that, by decreasing the local activity of H2O near the anode surface by substantially increasing the ionic strength of the electrolyte, the oxygen evolution reaction would be suppressed, leading concomitantly to a higher selectivity of Cl2 over O2 formation. Hence, the influence of the ionic strength on the competition between electrochem. evolution of O2 and Cl2 at dimensionally stable anodes (DSAs) was investigated. Addn. of a high concn. of NaNO3, an inert electrolyte additive, increases the selectivity for chlorine at high c.d., as detd. by means of online electrochem. mass spectrometry and UV-vis spectroscopy. We propose conditions in which free water is suppressed, owing to under-coordination of the solvation shells of ions, as a general concept to modulate the selectivity of competing electrochem. reactions.

The oxygen (OER) and chlorine (CLER) evolution reactions were used as probes to test the electronic properties of modified electrodes (Ti/TiO2-Pt). Both reactions were studied in acidic solns. by current-potential (j-E) and impedance measurements under steady state conditions. The effect of dopant concn., TiO2 thickness, and the concn. of the electroactive species in the soln. was analyzed. A diminution of the electron transfer current with titanium oxide thickness was obtained whereas an increase of the current was found on augmenting Pt amt. At low titanium oxide thickness both inner-sphere reactions behave in the same way as in the case of pure Pt, indicating that platinum sites are the active ones. However, at higher titanium oxide thickness, the platinum sites become less active and the valve metal oxide (TiO2) begins to block OER and CLER reactions. The electrochem. impedance spectroscopy results are compared with those of the current-potential measurements and a good correlation is found between them.

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and chlorine evolution reaction (CER) are electrochem. processes with high relevance to water splitting for (solar) energy conversion and industrial prodn. of commodity chems., resp. Carrying out the two reactions sep. is challenging, since the catalytic intermediates are linked by scaling relations. Optimizing the efficiency of OER over CER in acidic media has proven esp. difficult. In this regard, the OER vs. CER selectivity of manganese oxide (MnOx), a known OER catalyst is investigated. Thin films (∼5-20 nm) of MnOx were electrodeposited on glassy carbon-supported hydrous iridium oxide (IrOx/GC) in aq. chloride solns. of pH ∼0.9. Using rotating ring-disk electrode voltammetry and online electrochem. mass spectrometry, it was found that deposition of MnOx onto IrOx decreases the CER selectivity of the system in the presence of 30 mM Cl- from 86% to < 7%, making it a highly OER-selective catalyst. Detailed studies of the CER mechanism and ex-situ structure studies using SEM, TEM, and XPS suggest that the MnOx film is in fact not a catalytically active phase, but functions as a permeable overlayer that disfavors the transport of chloride ions.

A review; electrochem. will play a vital role in creating sustainable energy solns. in the future, particularly for the conversion and storage of elec. into chem. energy in electrolysis cells, and the reverse conversion and utilization of the stored energy in galvanic cells. The common challenge in both processes is the development of-preferably abundant-nanostructured materials that can catalyze the electrochem. reactions of interest with a high rate over a sufficiently long period of time. An overall understanding of the related processes and mechanisms occurring under the operation conditions is a necessity for the rational design of materials that meet these requirements. A promising strategy to develop such an understanding is the investigation of the impact of material properties on reaction activity/selectivity and on catalyst stability under the conditions of operation, as well as the application of complementary in situ techniques for the investigation of catalyst structure and compn.

Atomically dispersed precious metal catalysts have emerged as a frontier in catalysis. However, a robust, generic synthetic strategy toward atomically dispersed catalysts is still lacking, which has limited systematic studies revealing their general catalytic trends distinct from those of conventional nanoparticle (NP)-based catalysts. Herein, the authors report a general synthetic strategy toward atomically dispersed precious metal catalysts, which consists of trapping precious metal precursors on a heteroatom-doped carbonaceous layer coated on a C support and immobilizing them with a SiO2 layer during thermal activation. Through the trapping-and-immobilizing method, five atomically dispersed precious metal catalysts (Os, Ru, Rh, Ir, and Pt) could be obtained and served as model catalysts for unravelling catalytic trends for the O redn. reaction (ORR). Owing to their isolated geometry, the atomically dispersed precious metal catalysts generally showed higher selectivity for H2O2 prodn. than their NP counterparts for the ORR. Among the atomically dispersed catalysts, the H2O2 selectivity was changed by the types of metals, with atomically dispersed Pt catalyst showing the highest selectivity. A combination of exptl. results and d. functional theory calcns. revealed that the selectivity trend of atomically dispersed catalysts could be correlated to the binding energy difference between *OOH and *O species. In terms of 2 e- ORR activity, the atomically dispersed Rh catalyst showed the best activity. The authors' general approach to atomically dispersed precious metal catalysts may help in understanding their unique catalytic behaviors for the ORR.

Development and optimization of nonplatinum group metal (non-PGM) electrocatalysts for O redn. reaction (ORR), consisting of transition metal-N-C (M-N-C) framework, is hindered by the partial understanding of the reaction mechanisms and precise chem. of the active site or sites. The authors analyzed >45 M-N-C electrocatalysts synthesized from three different families of precursors, such as polymer-based, macrocycles, and small org. mols. Catalysts were electrochem. tested and analyzed structurally using exactly the same protocol for deriving structure-to-property relations. The authors have identified possible active sites participating in different ORR pathways: (1) metal-free electrocatalysts support partial redn. of O2 to H2O2; (2) pyrrolic N acts as a site for partial O2 redn. to H2O2; (3) pyridinic N displays catalytic activity in reducing H2O2 to H2O; (4) Fe coordinated to N (Fe-Nx) serves as an active site for four-electron (4e-) direct redn. of O2 to H2O. The ratio of the amt. of pyridinic and Fe-Nx to the amt. of pyrrolic N serves as a rational design metric of M-N-C electrocatalytic activity in O redn. reaction occurring through the preferred 4e- redn. to H2O.
